args: Put this article into one of the following categories. Use the most specific category that makes sense. If you are unsure, respond Other. The allowed categories are: Abortion, AI, Associated Press, Birthright citizenship, CFPB, Climate, Crypto, D.C., Debt ceiling, DEI in schools, DEI in the federal government, Department of Education, Deportations, DOGE, End birthright citizenship, Eric Adams case, Expanding executive power, Federal funding, Federal grant pause, Federal office space, Federal worker buyout, Federal workers return to office, Federal workforce reductions, FEMA, Firing government watchdogs, Food safety, Foreign aid, Foreign policy, Gaza, Government shutdown, Guantánamo Bay, Health agencies' communications pause, Health care, Immigration policy, Interest rates, Iran, Islamic State, Israel, Jan. 6, Kennedy Center, NIH, NYC congestion toll, Other, Panama Canal, Pardons, Reclassifying federal jobs, Sanctions, Senior government officials ousted, Taiwan, Targeting political enemies, Targeting protesters, Tariffs, The media, TikTok ban, Transgender policy, U.S.-Mexico border, USAID, USPS, War in Ukraine, World Health Organization Respond ONLY with the category. Trump signing executive order intended to reduce federal workforce President Donald Trump on Tuesday is signing an executive order that calls on federal agencies to work with the U.S. DOGE Service in a bid to cut their existing workforce and limit future hiring, a White House official told The Washington Post. The order calls on agency leaders to limit hiring to “essential” positions, prepare for large reductions in force and reduce backfills after staff departures. The order includes some exceptions, such as allowing more hiring of national security and law enforcement personnel. Semafor first reported that Trump will sign the executive order. Ahead of the signing, Trump was joined in the Oval Office by Elon Musk, his billionaire ally who is overseeing DOGE, an agency that Trump has empowered to find government efficiencies. Musk praised some federal workers but also criticized the “unelected” bureaucracy in remarks made to reporters in the room. DOGE’s actions — which include moving to dismantle some U.S. agencies, pushing out tens of thousands of civil servants and gaining access to some of the federal government’s most sensitive payment systems — have prompted lawsuits and fears that many of the actions are illegal.
